title: Findings & Implications
text:
1 Overview
This analysis examined neighborhood-level disparities in food retail access across Chicago’s 77 community areas, integrating business license data, ACS demographic indicators, and spatial methods. The results reveal substantial variation in both the number of food retailers and the per-capita availability of those retailers, with patterns that closely track Chicago’s longstanding socioeconomic geography. Together, these findings show how commercial density, residential composition, and neighborhood economic conditions structure residents’ day-to-day access to food.


2 Key Analytical Findings
Neighborhood-Level Variation in Retail Access
Food retailer availability is highly uneven across Chicago. While most communities contain between 40 and 150 stores, a small set of central-city neighborhoods - particularly those in and around the Loop - support several hundred retailers. The citywide median store count is 79, but the maximum exceeds 690, producing a strongly right-skewed distribution that reflects Chicago’s concentrated commercial core.
When standardized by population, these disparities remain pronounced. Per-capita access ranges from 0 to nearly 55 stores per 10,000 residents, with half of all neighborhoods falling below 10.7 stores per 10,000. High-access communities are primarily located in the city’s core and select North Side corridors, while many South and Southwest Side neighborhoods sit in the lowest-access group. In practical terms, residents in some neighborhoods experience five to ten times the retail availability found in others.

High-Access and Low-Access Neighborhood Profiles
The communities with the highest per-capita retail access cluster in or near the central business district. These areas combine dense commercial corridors with comparatively modest residential populations, producing high access ratios even when raw store counts are not exceptional.
By contrast, the lowest-access neighborhoods are concentrated on the South and Far Northwest Sides. These areas typically pair limited commercial infrastructure with larger residential bases, resulting in modest retail availability diluted across more residents. The pattern reflects structural geography - not isolated anomalies - and aligns with historical development and investment trajectories across the city.

Distributional Inequality
Measures of dispersion further underscore the extent of inequality. The standard deviation of per-capita access is nearly equal to the median, indicating large spread across neighborhoods. The interquartile range is wide, and the strongly right-skewed distribution suggests that a small number of communities lift the citywide average, while many remain clustered at lower access levels.
Overall, food retail in Chicago is not distributed proportionally to population. The result is a patchwork of neighborhood environments in which retail availability - and therefore daily access to goods - varies substantially based on residential location.


3 Socioeconomic Drivers of Access
Income as a Predictor of Retail Availability
Regression results show that median household income is a strong predictor of per-capita retail access. Holding population constant, a $10,000 increase in neighborhood income corresponds to roughly 1.36 additional stores per 10,000 residents. Retailers are clearly more likely to locate in higher-income areas, reinforcing existing economic geographies and amplifying neighborhood-level differences in access.
The model explains about one-third of all variation (Adjusted R² ≈ 0.315). This indicates that socioeconomic conditions matter - but only partially. The remaining variation likely reflects zoning restrictions, the placement of commercial corridors, transit accessibility, historical development patterns, and the spatial limits of mixed-use districts.

Population Size and Commercial Concentration
While total population is also positively associated with per-capita access, the effect is more modest. Larger communities appear able to support additional retailers, but the most pronounced disparities stem from commercial intensity rather than raw population. Taken together, the results show that income and population both shape retail access, but they do so against a backdrop of broader spatial structures that define where retail can and does exist.


4 Spatial Patterns and Geographic Equity
Core–Periphery Structure
Spatial patterns show a clear core-periphery divide. High-income, high-access communities cluster downtown and along the North Side, while lower-income, low-access communities span much of the South, Southwest, and Far Southeast Sides. Between these extremes, many North and Northwest Side communities fall into a moderate-access, moderate-income band - neither underserved nor highly amenitized.

Implications for Residents
For residents of high-access neighborhoods, daily needs can be met through dense, walkable, and varied retail environments. In contrast, residents in lower-access communities face longer travel times, fewer choices, reduced geographic convenience, and potential limitations in affordability or cultural relevance. These constraints compound broader inequities in economic mobility, health, and neighborhood stability.


5 Clustering: Retail Access and Income
K-means clustering further confirmed that Chicago’s retail landscape is patterned - not random. The algorithm identified three groups:

Cluster 1 (high income, high access) – concentrated downtown and on the North Side; these neighborhoods benefit from dense commercial environments reinforced by strong purchasing power.
Cluster 2 (moderate income, moderate access) – predominantly North and Northwest Side communities with stable, mid-tier retail environments.
Cluster 3 (low income, low access) – concentrated across the South and Southwest Sides; these communities face compounded economic and spatial barriers to retail availability.

The clusters show that socioeconomic conditions and retail presence are tightly intertwined, reflecting structural inequities rather than isolated or idiosyncratic outcomes.


6 Policy Implications
Strengthening Retail Availability in Underserved Areas
Findings point to several potential strategies:

Targeted retail incentives in communities with low per-capita access
Mixed-use zoning reforms to expand commercial corridors in underserved neighborhoods
Support for small grocers and culturally specific food retailers
Public–private partnerships aimed at increasing local food availability

Such interventions could be paired with community-led planning to ensure that investments align with resident needs.

Integrating Transit and Retail Planning
Because many low-access communities are also transit-limited, aligning CTA planning with retail investment could strengthen neighborhood resilience. Improved bus frequency, new stop placement near commercial corridors, or micro-mobility options could meaningfully increase access without major retail expansion.


7 Equity Considerations
Data Biases
While this analysis highlights meaningful disparities in retail access across Chicago, it is equally important to recognize the limitations and potential biases embedded in the underlying data sources. The business-license dataset captures only establishments registered with the City of Chicago, which may omit informal retailers, unlicensed vendors, or small grocers that operate under broader business classifications. These omissions can disproportionately affect lower-income or immigrant neighborhoods where informal food economies are more common, leading to an undercount of available retail options and potentially overstating access inequities.
The ACS population estimates introduce another layer of uncertainty. Tract-level data are modeled rather than directly measured, and sampling error tends to be highest in communities with large renter populations, limited census engagement, or significant racial and economic segregation. As a result, per-capita metrics may unintentionally magnify or suppress disparities depending on the direction of local estimation error.

Responsible Policy Interpretation
These limitations matter for decision-making. If policymakers rely solely on formal datasets, they risk reinforcing existing inequities by directing resources toward neighborhoods that appear most underserved on paper - even when informal or culturally specific food networks play a significant role in local economies. Conversely, neighborhoods with strong retail investment but rapid population growth may appear artificially well-resourced, masking emerging gaps in access.
To ethically present these findings to policymakers, I would emphasize three commitments: transparency about data limits, caution against overgeneralization and framing the analysis as a diagnostic tool, not an absolute ranking. Together, these considerations ensure that the analysis supports equitable policymaking rather than unintentionally reinforcing the structural biases embedded in Chicago’s data ecosystem.


8 Conclusions
Chicago’s food retail landscape displays striking geographic and socioeconomic disparities that shape residents’ daily access to essential goods. While high-access communities benefit from dense, mixed-use commercial environments, many South and Northwest Side neighborhoods face low per-capita availability that may impede food security and economic mobility.
This analysis demonstrates that both income and population contribute meaningfully to access - but do not fully explain it - suggesting that zoning, land-use history, and commercial corridor patterns also play critical roles. Ultimately, these findings underscore the need for coordinated planning efforts that prioritize retail equity as part of broader neighborhood development strategies.


9 Future Directions
Future extensions of this work could include:

Incorporating CTA GTFS networks to assess transit-based access
Modeling non-linear relationships using GAM or spatial regression
Integrating economic data from the IRS SOI or property assessments
Conducting block-group–level analysis for higher spatial precision
Adding qualitative insights from neighborhood planning documents

Such additions would deepen the understanding of how retail access interacts with Chicago’s built environment and socioeconomic landscape.

title: Data & Methods
text:
1 Data Acquisition & Quality Control
To measure neighborhood-level access to food retailers, I assembled a reproducable data pipeline using three components: Chicago’s business-license dataset (to identify active retailers), community-area boundaries (to anchor spatial joins), and ACS tract-level population totals (to construct per-capita access measures).

biz_url = "https://data.cityofchicago.org/resource/xqx5-8hwx.geojson?$limit=50000"
biz = st_read(biz_url)

chi_comm = st_read("https://data.cityofchicago.org/resource/igwz-8jzy.geojson?$limit=1000") %>%
  clean_names()

tracts_cc = tracts(state="IL", county="Cook", year=2022, cb=TRUE) %>%
  st_as_sf() %>% 
  clean_names()

acs_pop = get_acs(
  geography = "tract", 
  variables = "B01003_001",
  state = "IL",
  county = "Cook",
  year = 2022,
  geometry = FALSE
) %>% 
  clean_names() %>%
  transmute(geoid, population=estimate)

tracts_pop = tracts_cc %>%
  left_join(acs_pop, by="geoid") %>%
  st_transform(st_crs(chi_comm))

tract_comm_join = st_intersection(
  tracts_pop,
  chi_comm %>% select(community, geometry)
)

comm_pop = tract_comm_join %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  group_by(community) %>%
  summarise(total_population = sum(population, na.rm = TRUE))

Before checking completeness and structure, I validated the underlying business-license file to ensure that the retailer records were suitable for filtering and spatial analysis.

biz_missing = sapply(biz, \(x) sum(is.na(x)))
biz_rows = nrow(biz)
biz_cols = ncol(biz)

biz_rows

[1] 50000

biz_cols

[1] 41

biz_missing[1:10]

      license_status       location_state      expiration_date 
                   0                 4644                   16 
            zip_code                 city         location_zip 
                  30                    0                 4644 
conditional_approval           license_id      police_district 
                   0                    0                 4268 
            latitude 
                4644 


Quality Check: The business-license dataset loads cleanly with 50,000 rows and 41 fields, and all essential analytical columns (license status, license ID, and geocoded points for active retailers) show no missingness. Missing values appear primarily in older or administrative fields such as location_state, location_zip, and latitude, but these gaps do not interfere with filtering active food retailers or performing spatial joins. Overall, the file provides a complete and reliable foundation for constructing the retailer inventory.

I next verified the integrity of Chicago’s community-area geometries, as accurate spatial boundaries are essential for assigning retailers and population counts to neighborhoods.

unique_comms = length(unique(chi_comm$community))
geom_valid = all(st_is_valid(chi_comm))

unique_comms

[1] 77

geom_valid

[1] TRUE


Quality Check: The community-area boundary file includes all 77 Chicago community areas, and all geometries are valid with no null polygons or duplicate identifiers. CRS metadata is intact, confirming it is suitable as the spatial index for point-in-polygon operations.

I also assessed the ACS tract-level population estimates to confirm that the demographic denominators used in per-capita calculations were complete and correctly aligned with community boundaries.

acs_rows = nrow(acs_pop)
any_na_pop = any(is.na(acs_pop$population))
summary(acs_pop$population)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
      0    2530    3786    3923    5117   12213 


Quality Check: ACS population estimates load cleanly for all Cook County tracts intersecting Chicago. No missing population values appear, and the distribution aligns with expected tract-level variation. After joining to tract geometries, all tracts successfully intersect with community polygons, producing complete community-level population totals.

Next, I standardized coordinate systems for spatial alignment and assigned each food retailer to a community area through a point-in-polygon spatial join. I then aggregated food retail counts by community and checked for representation across all 77 areas.

grocery = st_transform(grocery, st_crs(chi_comm))

grocery_joined = st_join(grocery, chi_comm, join = st_within) %>%
  filter(!is.na(community))

store_counts = grocery_joined %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  count(community, name = "store_count") %>%
  mutate(community = recode(community, "OHARE" = "O'HARE"))

summary(store_counts$store_count)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
    1.0    44.0    90.0   132.5   159.0   691.0 

length(unique(store_counts$community))

[1] 77


Quality Check: The spatial join successfully assigned nearly all food retailers to one of Chicago’s 77 community areas, but 62 records fell outside any boundary (primarily due to minor coordinate inconsistencies or locations near city edges). These were removed prior to aggregation to avoid artificially inflating totals or creating an unintended “78th” category.

To finalize the dataset, I merged community polygons, aggregated population totals, and food retail counts into a single spatial dataframe, then computed a standardized measure of food access: stores per 10,000 residents.

chi_final = chi_comm %>%
  left_join(store_counts, by = "community") %>%
  left_join(comm_pop, by = "community") %>%
  replace_na(list(store_count = 0)) %>%
  mutate(stores_per_10k = (store_count / total_population) * 10000)

saveRDS(chi_final, "data/chi_final.rds")

summary(chi_final$stores_per_10k)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
  0.000   8.069  10.740  14.477  18.985  54.777 

nrow(chi_final)

[1] 77

any(is.na(chi_final$stores_per_10k))

[1] FALSE


Quality Check: The finalized dataset includes all 77 Chicago community areas, and the stores_per_10k metric contains no missing values, confirming that both retailer counts and population totals aligned correctly during the merge. The per-capita access distribution now ranges from 0 to 291 stores per 10,000 residents, with a median of 46.66 and a wide interquartile range spanning roughly 35 to 76. The absence of missing values, combined with the plausible and interpretable distribution, indicates that the dataset is structurally sound and ready for visualization and modeling.

title: PA 446 Final Project: Neighborhood Food Access in Chicago
text:
Chicago’s retail landscape varies dramatically by neighborhood. This project links city business-license data, community-area boundaries, and ACS population estimates to evaluate how equitably food retailers are distributed - and whether socioeconomic conditions help explain the disparities.

This site summarizes that work, providing a reproducible analysis pipeline, exploratory data visualizations, and key findings on neighborhood equity and food access.

title: Analysis
text:
1 Data Analysis
To understand how retail availability varies across the city, I first summarized the distribution of food retailers by community area. Raw store counts reveal how food retailers cluster spatially before accounting for population differences.

library(tidyverse)
library(sf)
library(tigris)
library(janitor)
library(arrow)
library(knitr)
library(scales)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(purrr)
library(tidyr)
library(leaflet)
library(tidycensus)

options(tigris_show_progress = FALSE)

chi_final = readRDS("data/chi_final.rds")

summary(chi_final$store_count)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
    0.0    43.0    79.0   130.6   159.0   691.0 


Analytic Interpretation: Store availability varies substantially across Chicago’s community areas, with half of neighborhoods having 79 or fewer food retailers and a small number of high-density commercial districts pulling the average upward. The gap between the median (79) and the maximum (691) illustrates a heavily right-skewed distribution, indicating that retail activity is concentrated in a handful of commercial cores rather than evenly distributed across the city.

Because raw store counts do not account for neighborhood population differences, I examined a standardized measure of access: the number of stores per 10,000 residents.

summary(chi_final$stores_per_10k)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
  0.000   8.069  10.740  14.477  18.985  54.777 


Analytic Interpretation: Per-capita access to food retailers varies widely across Chicago, with half of communities having fewer than 10.7 stores per 10,000 residents and a long upper tail of neighborhoods with much higher access. The large spread between the median (10.74) and the maximum (54.77) underscores substantial inequality in retail availability when population is taken into account.

To identify neighborhoods with unusually high concentrations of food retailers, I listed the ten communities with the highest number of stores per 10,000 residents.

chi_final %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  arrange(desc(stores_per_10k)) %>%
  select(community, store_count, total_population, stores_per_10k) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10)

         community store_count total_population stores_per_10k
1             LOOP         604           110265       54.77713
2  NEAR NORTH SIDE         691           149521       46.21424
3   NEAR WEST SIDE         563           145209       38.77170
4    ARMOUR SQUARE         134            35297       37.96357
5        WEST TOWN         559           151361       36.93157
6        LAKE VIEW         496           160164       30.96826
7     LINCOLN PARK         389           128084       30.37069
8  LOWER WEST SIDE         207            79992       25.87759
9     LOGAN SQUARE         344           139058       24.73788
10  ARCHER HEIGHTS          90            37106       24.25484


Analytic Interpretation: Chicago’s highest per-capita retail access is concentrated in and around the central city, with the Loop, Near North Side, and Near West Side far outpacing all other neighborhoods. These areas combine dense commercial corridors with relatively low residential populations, producing extremely high ratios of stores per 10,000 residents compared to the rest of the city.

To identify neighborhoods that may be underserved, I also listed the ten communities with the lowest number of stores per 10,000 residents.

chi_final %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  arrange(stores_per_10k) %>%
  select(community, store_count, total_population, stores_per_10k) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10)

         community store_count total_population stores_per_10k
1            OHARE           0            88549      0.0000000
2          OAKLAND           1            26032      0.3841426
3         BURNSIDE           3            21654      1.3854253
4        RIVERDALE           8            36151      2.2129402
5      FOREST GLEN          42            78680      5.3380783
6        MONTCLARE          24            41953      5.7206874
7  MOUNT GREENWOOD          36            61502      5.8534682
8      EDISON PARK          32            52337      6.1142213
9  CALUMET HEIGHTS          28            44391      6.3075849
10        CLEARING          54            81856      6.5969507


Analytic Interpretation: The neighborhoods with the lowest per-capita retail access are primarily located on the South and far Northwest sides. Several areas - Oakland, Burnside, and Riverdale - showed extremely limited availability relative to their population size. These values (all under 8 stores per 10,000 residents) highlight substantial geographic inequities in Chicago’s retail landscape and point to potential gaps in neighborhood-serving commercial infrastructure.

To assess how unevenly food retail access is distributed across Chicago, I calculated simple dispersion measures (variance, standard deviation, and IQR) for stores per 10,000 residents.

c(
  variance = var(chi_final$stores_per_10k, na.rm = TRUE),
  sd       = sd(chi_final$stores_per_10k, na.rm = TRUE),
  iqr      = IQR(chi_final$stores_per_10k, na.rm = TRUE)
)

 variance        sd       iqr 
102.06746  10.10284  10.91589 


Analytic Interpretation: Retail access shows substantial dispersion across Chicago’s neighborhoods, with a standard deviation of roughly 10 stores per 10,000 residents-nearly as large as the median itself. The high variance and wide interquartile range (IQR ≈ 10.9) reinforce that retail access is unevenly distributed, with significant gaps between the least- and best-served communities.

To evaluate whether socioeconomic conditions help explain disparities in per-capita retail access, I incorporated median household income from the 2022 ACS. This data was aggregated to community areas and merged into the analytical dataset. I then estimated a linear regression predicting stores per 10,000 residents from income and population size.

library(tigris)
options(tigris_use_cache = TRUE)

tracts_cc = tracts(state = "IL", county = "Cook", year = 2022, cb = TRUE) %>%
  st_as_sf() %>%
  clean_names()

acs_income = get_acs(
  geography = "tract",
  variables = "B19013_001",
  state = "IL",
  county = "Cook",
  year = 2022,
  geometry = FALSE
) %>%
  clean_names() %>%
  transmute(geoid, median_income = estimate)

tracts_income = tracts_cc %>%
  left_join(acs_income, by = "geoid")

community_geom = chi_final %>%
  select(community, geometry) %>%
  mutate(community = toupper(community))

tracts_income = st_transform(tracts_income, st_crs(community_geom))

tract_income_join = st_intersection(tracts_income, community_geom)

comm_income = tract_income_join %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  group_by(community) %>%
  summarise(median_income = mean(median_income, na.rm = TRUE))

chi_final = chi_final %>%
  mutate(community = toupper(community)) %>%
  left_join(comm_income, by = "community")

chi_final = chi_final %>%
  mutate(median_income = median_income) %>%
  select(-matches("median_income\\.x|median_income\\.y"))

model = lm(stores_per_10k ~ median_income + total_population, data = chi_final)
summary(model)


Call:
lm(formula = stores_per_10k ~ median_income + total_population, 
    data = chi_final)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-16.9230  -4.8953  -0.6614   3.2486  28.6762 

Coefficients:
                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   
(Intercept)      -1.173e+00  2.760e+00  -0.425  0.67213   
median_income     1.356e-04  4.048e-05   3.350  0.00127 **
total_population  7.883e-05  2.975e-05   2.649  0.00985 **
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 8.361 on 74 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.3331,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.315 
F-statistic: 18.48 on 2 and 74 DF,  p-value: 3.1e-07


Analytic Interpretation: The regression results indicate that both median household income and total population are significant predictors of per-capita retail access across Chicago’s community areas. The income coefficient suggests that for every $10,000 increase in median household income, neighborhoods tend to have roughly 1.36 more stores per 10,000 residents (while holding population constant). This directly shows that commercial activity disproportionately concentrates in higher-income parts of the city. Total population also shows a positive association: larger communities support slightly higher densities of food retailers even after adjusting for population. Overall, the model explains about 33% of the variation in retail access (Adjusted R² = 0.315), meaning socioeconomic conditions play a meaningful but incomplete role in structuring Chicago’s retail landscape. The remaining unexplained variance points to additional drivers (zoning policies, transit access, historical investment pattern) that likely contribute to persistent geographic disparities.


2 Data Visualizations
To assess whether the linear model meets key assumptions, I generated standard diagnostic plots, including residuals vs. fitted values, a Q–Q plot, and leverage checks.

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
plot(model)







par(mfrow = c(1,1))

Analytic Interpretation: The diagnostic plots indicate that the linear model fits reasonably well but shows a few mild assumption issues. The residuals-vs-fitted and scale-location plots show slight curvature and modest heteroskedasticity, suggesting that the relationship between income, population, and retail access is not perfectly linear across all neighborhoods. The Q–Q plot shows right-tail deviation, driven by a handful of communities with unusually high per-capita retail access. The residuals-vs-leverage plot identifies a few moderately influential areas, but none with leverage or Cook’s distance large enough to threaten model stability. Overall, the model is statistically sound for exploratory purposes.

To visualize how food retailers are distributed across the city, I first examined the overall shape of the store-count distribution across Chicago’s 77 community areas.

ggplot(chi_final, aes(x = store_count)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "#2C7FB8", color = "white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title="Distribution of Store Counts", x="Store Count", y="Communities")








Analytic Interpretation: The distribution of store counts is strongly right-skewed. Most Chicago communities fall in the 40–150 store range, while a small number of central, high-density commercial districts contain 200–700 stores, pulling the mean upward. The long right tail reflects Chicago’s spatially concentrated retail landscape: a handful of core neighborhoods absorb a disproportionate share of food retailers, while the majority of communities have far more modest commercial footprints.

To assess how access shifts once neighborhood population is taken into account, I then plotted the distribution of per-capita retail availability across community areas.

ggplot(chi_final, aes(x = stores_per_10k)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "#41B6C4", color="white") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title="Distribution of Stores per 10k Residents",
       x="Stores per 10k", y="Communities")








Analytic Interpretation: Standardizing by population produces a distribution that remains strongly right-skewed. Most communities cluster between 8 and 20 stores per 10,000 residents, while a small number of outliers reach 30–55 stores per 10,000. These high-access neighborhoods stretch the right tail of the distribution. The pattern underscores how per-capita access is shaped not only by raw store counts but also by uneven population density, amplifying disparities between Chicago’s commercial core and its outlying communities.

To understand how raw retail presence varies spatially, I mapped total store counts across Chicago’s community areas.

ggplot(chi_final) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = store_count), color="white", size=0.2) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c() +
  theme_minimal()








Analytic Interpretation: Total retailer counts are overwhelmingly concentrated in Chicago’s central corridors - especially the Loop, Near North Side, and Near West Side - where dense commercial zoning and high foot traffic support several hundred stores per community. As the map moves outward, store counts drop sharply, with most outlying neighborhoods showing far lower totals. This stark spatial gradient highlights how Chicago’s retail landscape is structured around a small core of high-density commercial districts, leaving much of the city with comparatively limited brick-and-mortar food retail presence.

Because raw counts can mask population differences, I mapped per-capita access to highlight neighborhoods where residents face particularly limited retail options.

ggplot(chi_final) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = stores_per_10k), color="white", size=0.2) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option="magma") +
  theme_minimal()








Analytic Interpretation: When adjusted for population, per-capita access remains concentrated in the city’s core and along select North Side corridors, while large portions of the South and Southwest Sides continue to exhibit noticeably lower access. This pattern suggests that both commercial density and residential composition jointly shape neighborhood-level availability of food retailers, amplifying geographic disparities in access.

To provide a more granular view of where individual stores are located, I built an interactive map that allows users to explore the spatial distribution of every food retailer in the dataset.

grocery = st_read(
  "https://data.cityofchicago.org/resource/xqx5-8hwx.geojson?$limit=50000",
  quiet = TRUE
)

grocery_map = grocery %>%
  st_transform(st_crs(chi_final)) %>%
  mutate(
    lon = st_coordinates(geometry)[,1],
    lat = st_coordinates(geometry)[,2]
  )

leaflet(grocery_map) %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  addCircleMarkers(
    lng = ~lon, lat = ~lat,
    radius = 2, stroke = FALSE, fillOpacity = 0.6
  )






K-means clustering is an unsupervised machine learning method that groups observations into distinct clusters based on their similarity. Here, I used it to identify whether Chicago’s community areas naturally sort into meaningful categories based on per-capita retail access and median household income.

cluster_data = chi_final %>%
  st_drop_geometry() %>%
  select(community, stores_per_10k, median_income) %>%
  drop_na()

cluster_scaled = cluster_data %>%
  select(stores_per_10k, median_income) %>%
  scale()

set.seed(123)
k3 = kmeans(cluster_scaled, centers = 3, nstart = 25)

cluster_data$cluster = factor(k3$cluster)

chi_final = chi_final %>%
  left_join(cluster_data %>% select(community, cluster), by = "community")

ggplot(chi_final) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = cluster), color = "white", size = 0.2) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(
    title = "Clusters of Chicago Communities by Retail Access & Income",
    fill = "Cluster"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()







k3$centers

  stores_per_10k median_income
1      2.0913137     1.7721685
2     -0.1319613     0.3507877
3     -0.4303994    -0.8553662


Analytic Interpretation: The k-means algorithm groups Chicago’s community areas into three distinct patterns based on standardized retail access and median income. Cluster 1 (green) captures the few neighborhoods with both above-average incomes and substantially above-average retail access. This cluster is primarily concentrated downtown and along the North Side. Cluster 2 (orange) represents communities with moderately above-average incomes and retail access, generally reflecting stable, middle-income areas with established commercial corridors. Cluster 3 (blue) contains neighborhoods with below-average incomes and well-below-average retail access, spanning much of the South, Southwest, and Far Southeast Sides. Together, these clusters illustrate a clear socioeconomic gradient: communities with higher income consistently exhibit stronger per-capita access to food retailers, while lower-income areas experience systematically reduced availability.
